details.purpose: To record results from an audiology speech test conducted for the purpose of assessing speech discrimination and speech recognition, and their clinical interpretation.
details.use:
Use to record the results of audiology speech tests carried out to assess speech discrimination and speech recognition.
Use to record the clinical interpretation of audiology speech tests carried out to assess speech discrimination and speech recognition.
details.misuse:
Not to be used for audiology speech testing that is used for phonemic confusions analysis.
Not to be used to assess speech production.
Not to be used to record audiology speech tests where the presentaton level is not known - for example: unmonitored live voice.

description.other_contributors: Kathy Currie, Northern Territory Health, Australia
Kerrie Lee, Ngaanyatjarra Health Service, Australia
Ian McNicoll, Ocean Informatics UK, United Kingdom
description.other_details:
Taylor B. Predicting Real World Hearing Aid Benefit with Speech Audiometry: An Evidence-Based Review; 2007 May 07 [cited 2013 Feb 08]. Available from: http://www.audiologyonline.com/articles/predicting-real-world-hearing-aid-946.
Madel J, Flexer C. Pediatric Audiology: Diagnosis, Technology, and Management. Thieme Medical Publishers; 2008. Chapter 10, Evaluation of Speech Perception in Infants and Children, p89-105.
Gordon-Salant S. Age-related differences in speech recognition performance as a function of test format and paradigm. Ear Hear. 1987 Oct;8(5):277-82. PubMed PMID: 3678641.
Nilsson M, Soli S D, Sullivan, J A. Development of the Hearing In Noise Test for the measurement of speech reception thresholds in quiet and in noise. Acoust. Soc. Am. 95, 1085 (1994), DOI:10.1121/1.408469.

items.description: Record of results from an audiology speech test conducted for the purpose of assessing speech discrimination and speech recognition, and their clinical interpretation.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The method used to present the speech test stimulus. (synthesised)
Identification of the audiology speech test performed.
The test measurements and interpretations which can be recorded per ear, or for both ears simultaneously.
The ear to which to the speech signal is presented.
The test stimuli were presented to the left ear only.
The test stimuli were presented to the right ear only.
The test stimuli were presented to both ears simultaneously in a soundfield.
Results obtained for performance intensity function at each test level.
The stimulus intensity.
Details about the responses correct of the subject being tested.
Percentage of words to which the test subject responds correctly.
Percentage of elements to which the test subject responds correctly.
A measure to compare a sample mean and a population mean.
Details of the adaptive test protocol.
The mean dB loudness level of the speech stimuli required to achieve the target correct performance.
The relationship of the loudness of the speech signal in dB to the loudness level of the noise stimulus.
Clinical interpretation of all responses for the identified test ear.
Overall clinical interpretation of the responses for both ears.
Additional narrative about the test results and intepretation not captured in other fields.
Indication regarding use of an assistive listening device by the test subject during the test.
The test has been conducted with the patient using a form of auditory assistance, such as a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
The test has been conducted without the patient using any form of auditory assistance, such as a hearing aid or cochlear implant.
Identification of type of assistive listening device used.
A type of hearing device.
A type of hearing device.
A type of hearing device.
Narrative description of the details of the assistive listening device settings.
The type of noise used in a speech test measuring speech perception in noise. (synthesised)
Contralateral masking signal was presented to the non test ear.
Masking noise is presented to the non test ear.
No masking noise is presented.
The method used to present the constralateral masking test signal.
A device that converts electric signals to audible sound and fits over or in the ear.
A listening condition in which the listener is 1 metre from a loud speaker and hears sounds presented via the loud speaker.
The level of the contralateral masking speech spectrum noise in dB.
Type of signal used as a competing signal during Signal to Noise Ratio testing.
Noise that has the same power at all frequencies (i.e., a flat power spectrum).

Noise spectrum that approximates the average long term spectrum of adult male speech and has a slope below 100 Hz of +6 dB/octave, a flat spectrum between 100 Hz and 320 Hz, and above 320 Hz a slope of -6 dB/octave.
A recording of the voices of many people who are talking simultaneously, resulting in an unintelligible babble.
The masker is a single person speaking and this speaker is different to the speaker used for the test stimulus.
Number of voices used to generate multispeaker babble.
Scale used for acoustic calibration check.
The sound pressure level scale was used.
The hearing level scale was used.
The specified percentage correct used to setup the adaptive test protocol.
The mode by which the speech test stimuli are presented.
Presentation of the speech test stimuli by monitored live voice presentation by the tester.
Presentation of the speech test stimuli from a recorded medium.
The method used to present the speech test stimulus.
The stimulus is presented via external headphones - either circumaural or supraaural..
The stimulus is presented via a loudspeaker located at least one metre away from the subject.
The type of response the patient is asked to give after hearing each stimulus.
The person repeats the stimulus item that was heard.
The test subject points to a picture of the stimulus item that was heard.
The test subject points to written text that corresponds to the stimulus item that was heard.
The size of the response set.
The size of the response set is unlimited.
The size of the response set is limited.
The response set is limited and the response alternatives remain constant for the whole test list.
The number of response alternatives offered in the Closed Set.
The number of response items offered in the Closed Task Domain.
The type of speech stimulus used for the speech test.
A consonant-vowel (CV) or CCV or VC or VCC item that is not a real word but is phonotactically correct.
Nonsense word comprising a consonant, then a vowel, then a final consonant, for example, "wub" or "yat".
A speech stimulus that is not a real word but is phonotactically correct.
A word comprised of a single syllable. For example, 'green'.
A word comprised of 2 syllables with equal stress on each syllable. For example, 'sunshine'.
A word that is comprised of two syllables with stress on the first syllable. For example 'bucket'.
A grammatical unit of one or more words that expresses an independent statement, question, request, command, exclamation, etc.
A term used in inferential statistics that measures the probability that a population parameter will fall between two set values.
No test result is available for the test ear.
Reason why no result is available for the test ear.
The number of reverals in an adaptive threshold test used for calculating estimates of a given test result.
Details about the specific assistive listening device used during the test.
The type of noise used in a speech test measuring speech perception in noise.
The noise is presented to the same ear as the speech signal.
The noise is presented to the ear opposite to the speech signal.
The subject response is to point to a 3 dimensional (i.e., concrete) object.
The type of adaptive test used. Typically either in quiet or in noise.
The speech signal is presented in optimal listening conditions, without any interference from other auditory signals.
The ratio of the signal intensity to the noise intensity.
The number of dB by which the stimullus intensity is changed after each response.
The initial presentation level in dB.
The initial signal to noise ratio level in dB. For example, +20 dB.
The method used to present the speech test stimulus.
An auditory stimulus is presented to the test subject.
A combination of auditory and visual stimuli are presented to the test subject.
A visual stimulus is presented to the test subject.
The A-weighted decibels of the sound pressure level scale were used.
The stimulus is presented via insert earphones.
Loudness
(added by post-parse processor)
The ear to which to the speech signal is presented. (synthesised)
Indication regarding use of an assistive listening device by the test subject during the test. (synthesised)
Identification of type of assistive listening device used. (synthesised)
Contralateral masking signal was presented to the non test ear. (synthesised)
The type of adaptive test used. Typically either in quiet or in noise. (synthesised)
The mode by which the speech test stimuli are presented. (synthesised)
The method used to present the speech test stimulus. (synthesised)
The type of response the patient is asked to give after hearing each stimulus. (synthesised)
The size of the response set. (synthesised)
The type of speech stimulus used for the speech test. (synthesised)
Type of signal used as a competing signal during Signal to Noise Ratio testing. (synthesised)
The method used to present the constralateral masking test signal. (synthesised)
Scale used for acoustic calibration check. (synthesised)
